ground_truth: The other two Vs are: 1. Veracity: Refers to the quality and accuracy of data. question: Give examples of Big Data implementation in your respective fields
ground_truth: Here are some examples of Big Data implementation in various fields: 1. Social Media Sentiment Analysis: Companies can use Big Data to analyze sentiment on social media towards their brand, product or service. By monitoring millions of tweets, Facebook posts, and other online reviews, they can understand customer views in real-time, identify trends, and respond quickly to changing perceptions or emerging issues. 2. Health Data Processing: In the health sector, Big Data is used to analyze clinical, genomic and other patient data to discover patterns, trends, and associations that can assist in disease diagnosis, drug development, and more effective and personalized treatment planning. 3. Supply Chain Optimization: Companies operating in the manufacturing or retail industry use Big Data to optimize their supply chains. By analyzing data related to customer demand, inventory, and production processes, they can identify areas where efficiency can be improved, reduce costs, and increase customer satisfaction by ensuring the right product is available at the right time.

answer: I come from a health nutrition study program, so the field I study is of course related to food, consumption, and health. One of the things that must be fulfilled and is a crucial component in people's diet is related to food safety. WHO recently used a Big Data approach to support decision-making in food safety resulting in the food safety platform FOSCOLLAB, to provide integration of various scientific disciplines. In this platform, structured and unstructured data from various sectors such as animal, agricultural, food, public health and economic indicators are integrated and made available to users through several dedicated dashboards. Data sources connected to FOSCOLLAB are Evaluations from the Joint FAO WHO Expert Committee on Food Additives JECFA and The Joint FAO WHO Meeting on Pesticide Residues JMPR data base regarding chemical risk assessment, the WHO database at the Collaborating Center and GEMS food regarding food consumption and chemical content in food. Information from additional data will be integrated as the FOSCOLLAB platform develops, which will support actors operating in food and feed risk analysis, for example in analyzing the risk of contamination or contamination contained in a food ingredient.

With this application, researchers can reduce experiments carried out by trial and error so that research can be made more efficient in terms of time and economy. What is meant is inventory control, which is an important part of a pharmacy's ability to manage patient care and maintain pharmacy profits. One example of the application of inventory control is archiving patient medical records along with a history of medications consumed and allergies in a database that can be accessed through permits from one hospital to another. Sources of research data can come from social media Twitter and Facebook. Next, the text preprocessing stage will be carried out. After the text has been processed and has become clean text, it will proceed to the classification process stage. In the classification process, the Nave Bayes Classifier method can be used to determine the sentiment of an opinion sentence. The final stage is to evaluate the performance of Accuracy, Precision, Recall and Error using the Confusion Matrix method. - Marketing a. answer: 1. UNITEDHEALTHCARE: FRAUD, WASTE, AND ABUSE Currently, at least 10% of health insurance payments are related to fraudulent claims. Worldwide, this is estimated to be worth billions of dollars. Fraudulent claims are not a new problem, but the complexity of insurance fraud seems to be increasing exponentially, making it difficult for health insurance companies to deal with it. UnitedHealthCare is an insurance company that provides health benefits and services to nearly 51 million people. The company works with more than 850,000 healthcare workers and approximately 6,100 hospitals nationwide. Their Payment Integrity group is tasked with ensuring that claims are paid correctly and on time. Previously, their approach to managing over a million claims per day, approximately 10 TB of data per day, was ad hoc, highly regulatory, and hampered by fragmented data. UnitedHealthCare’s solution was a dual-mode approach, focusing on allocating savings while also implementing innovation to continue to leverage the latest technology. 2. HADOOP TECHNOLOGY FOR MONITORING PATIENT VITAL CONDITIONS Hadoop is an open source framework or platform based on Java under the Apache license to support applications that run on Big Data. Several hospitals around the world have used Hadoop to help their staff work efficiently with Big Data. Without Hadoop, most healthcare systems would find it nearly impossible to analyze unstructured data. Childrens Healthcare of Atlanta uses bedside sensors to track patient vital conditions such as heart rate, breathing and blood pressure. These sensors can produce very large data and the system is unable to process the data because storing the data requires large storage and costs. In fact, this hospital needs to store vital data for analysis. If there is a change in pattern, a notification is needed for the team of doctors and staff. 3. VALENCE HEALTH: IMPROVING SERVICE QUALITY AND REIMBURSEMENTS Valence Health uses Hadoop to build a data lake which is the company's main data storage. Valence processes 3000 inbound data feeds with 45 types of data every day. answer: Google translate is one of the results of implementing the use of big data. Even though it's only a dictionary, Google Translate also takes big data from various articles, posts and online news. This is what allows us to translate a full paragraph into Google Translate -- even though the results are not always accurate. Big data from Google Translate can be seen when there are gender issues in the translation. For example, when translating into English he works at home, it will output SHE works at home, whereas if he works as a lawyer, it will output HE works as a lawyer. SHE and HE who replaced him were obtained not because the developers of Google Translate had problems and gender bias, but rather gender problems that already existed in society, through news, posts and writings which were then used by Google Translate.

Big Data is also applied in the transportation sector, because traffic jams often occur in several big cities in Indonesia. With GPS data owned by city residents' vehicles, it can be converted into speed, acceleration and stopping duration. This conversion data can be used to provide recommendations to the public about the best times to drive and the worst times to travel. Industrial sector: - To avoid the high costs associated with supply chain failure, a company will look for better ways to manage the delivery of raw materials. The industry will decide to use detailed supplier route data, as well as weather and traffic data provided by reliable external sources, to identify possible delivery delays. Using Big Data, they carry out predictive analysis and calculate possible delays and shortages of raw materials. Based on these calculations, companies can make contingency plans regarding inventory and now they can run their production without interruption and of course avoid excessive downtime costs.

answer: Pharmacies need to collect data on the number of prescriptions, drug redemptions, frequency of purchases, and so on. In the pharmaceutical sector, an example of the application of big data is that the pharmaceutical company Kimia Farma launched the Kimia Farma Mobile application which has been connected and integrated with more than 1,300 Kimia Farma pharmacies throughout Indonesia. This application is equipped with big data analytic technology to facilitate the inventory, control and monitoring process from the center to each outlet from the sales side. Apart from that, it is also useful for making it easier to find medicines at the pharmacy. The data can be used to track drug shortages and the reasons why they occur. The use of data can help pharmaceutical departments manage the reverse distribution process by tracking when drug supplies will run out based on buyer habits. Data can also minimize excess inventory by providing the frequency with which unpopular medications are used. Data helps pharmacists improve operational efficiency and costs. Inventory control is a critical part of a pharmacy's ability to manage patient care and maintain profitability. Data allows for more accurate inventory tracking, so supply disruptions do not occur and pharmacists can take advantage of bulk purchases and special price offers. Through data availability, Big Data can drive treatment adherence and better patient outcomes. Using data, pharmacists can make treatment recommendations based on elements such as diet, supplements, drug education and medication adherence.

question: Mention and briefly explain the characteristics of a data collection called Big Data
ground_truth: The characteristics of a data collection called Big Data are often summarized by the "5Vs": 1. Volume: Refers to the enormous amount of data generated every day. 2. Velocity: Indicates the rate at which new data is generated and how quickly it needs to be processed. 3. Variety: Describes the different types and sources of data available, including structured, unstructured, and semi-structured data. 4. Veracity: Relates to the quality and accuracy of data. 5. Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. These characteristics highlight the scale, complexity, and diversity of Big Data, which require specialized processing and analysis techniques to extract valuable insights.
answer: Data is called Big Data when the amount of data is so large, fast or complex that it is difficult or impossible to process using traditional methods.

answer: In simple terms, a data set to be called Big Data has the following characteristics, namely: The data contained in the data set is very large and continues to grow exponentially over time.  The large amount of data means that the data collection cannot be processed and analyzed using conventional data processing methods.  If data mining, data storage, data analysis, data sharing, and data visualization are used to collect large amounts of data, it is necessary to apply Big Data concepts because the amount is very large. If explained further, several characteristics of a collection of data called Big Data are: Volume means that data can be categorized into Big Data if it has a large size or it is possible that it can grow very quickly so that it requires very large storage.  Variety means that data can be called Big Data if it has various characteristics and is not homogeneous, but has many variables and is very diverse, including various types of data, both data that has been structured in a database and data that is not organized in a database.  Velocity means Big Data has the characteristic of changing very quickly both in terms of variables and data types. With these characteristics, a special touch is needed in processing Big Data.  Veracity means Big Data has vulnerabilities in terms of accuracy and validity so it requires depth to analyze Big Data in order to produce the right decisions.  Value means that Big Data has very high value if it is processed in an appropriate way. Thus, it is clear that Big Data is not only about very large sizes but also has characteristics such as very diverse types of data and very high rates of growth and frequency of change.

Variety: Describes the different types and sources of data available, including structured, unstructured, and semi-structured data. 4. Veracity: Relates to the quality and accuracy of data. 5. Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. These characteristics highlight the scale, complexity, and diversity of Big Data, which require specialized processing and analysis techniques to extract valuable insights.
answer: variety, grouping characteristics of structured, unstructured and semi-structured data velocity, the speed of connecting incoming data in real time volume, the amount of data stored

Value: Refers to the value or information that can be obtained from Big Data processing. answer: According to Eaton, Dirk, Tom, George, Paul, Big Data is a term that applies to information that cannot be processed or analyzed using traditional tools.  According to Dumbill, 2012, Big Data is data that exceeds the processing capacity of existing database system conventions. Because the data is too large and too fast or does not match the existing database architectural structure, to get value from the data, you have to choose an alternative way so that it can be processed.  So, in general, Big Data is data with large volumes that cannot be processed using ordinary traditional tools and must use new methods and tools to get value from this data.

question: What are the 3 differences between a relational database and a data warehouse?
ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: 1. Relational Database The Relational Database Model presents data in two-dimensional tables, like a spreadsheet, only it is not presented in a table like a spreadsheet but uses a combination or joining of relational tables to produce a view or display results. 2. Data Warehouse Data Warehouse Model, also known as enterprise data warehouse is a system used for data reporting and analysis and is considered a core component of business intelligence.

Data warehouse: Data warehouse organizes and processes large amounts of historical data and provides several facilities. Data warehouses store and process data according to different levels of granularity.  Data warehouse systems generally adopt snowflake or star modeling and subject-oriented design.  Data warehouses often span various types of database schemas due to the evolutionary process of an organization. Data warehouses also deal with various information obtained from several other organizations, which combine from various data storage places. This will cause very large volumes so that warehouse data is stored in several storage areas.  The access pattern in the data warehouse is mostly read only. This is because most of the data stored is historical data and only a little new data.

Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: The differences between relational databases and data warehouses are: Relational databases are used in OLTP Online Processing Transactions and can be used for data warehouse needs, and are customer oriented and used in query and transaction processes.  The data warehouse is used in Online Analytical Processing OLAP which is capable of reading historical data for users in the decision making process, and is market oriented and used in the data analysis process by people who have professional knowledge fields.

answer: Database systems generally use data entity relationship modeling and application-oriented design, while data warehouse systems generally use snowflake or star modeling and subject-oriented design.  Databases focus on real time data in an organization or agency without referring to historical data or data from other organizations, while data warehouses often cover various types of database schemas due to the evolutionary process of an organization. Data warehouses also deal with various information obtained from several other organizations, which combine from various data storage places. This will cause very large volumes so that warehouse data is stored in several storage areas.  Access patterns in databases mainly consist of short atomic transactions and systems like this require concurency control and recovery mechanisms, while access patterns in data warehouses are mostly read only. This is because most of the data stored is historical data and only a little new data.  Databases are used in Transactional Online Processing OLTP and can also be used for data warehouse needs, while data warehouses are used in Online Analytical Processing OLAP which is able to read historical data for users in the decision making process. The tables and combinations in the database are very complex so they can reduce redundant data and save storage space., while Tables and joins in the data warehouse are relatively simple to reduce response times and analytical requests.

ground_truth: The three main differences between a relational database and a data warehouse are: 1. Intended Use: Relational databases are designed for daily transactional and operational data (OLTP), while data warehouses are designed for data analysis and business reporting (OLAP). 2. Data Structure: Relational databases use a structured schema with tables, rows, and columns, whereas data warehouses use a format optimized for querying and analysis, often using a star schema or snow schema. 3. Optimization: Relational databases are optimized for speed and efficiency in processing small to medium data transactions in real-time, whereas data warehouses are optimized for big data processing and analysis, supporting complex and data-intensive read operations.
answer: A warehouse is a broad scope of storage and processing from various data sources, not only relational databases, which are integrated and easy to display information in drilldown or rollup. The commonly used relational database is the OLTP online transaction process area. Meanwhile, the data warehouse is the second stage, where data is no longer queried in large quantities and normalized, but the data has been aggregated according to the needs of the analysis report and has been normalized.

Currently, hackers and Big Data security continue to be developed continuously to ensure that systems that use Big Data are safe from data breaches or other forms of information theft and of course this requires quite frequent design changes or code updates. Even though this process takes a lot of time and energy. In addition, along with the times and innovations in the implementation of new technology, the types of data become increasingly diverse, the size of available data will grow exponentially. Moreover, considering that big data management is much different from conventional relational databases, sorting the desired data from the incoming data set is quite difficult.  Data Availability One of the keys to conducting Big Data analysis is of course data availability. Access to data, both old data and new data, can be an obstacle for Big Data, especially old data which is stored in different and varied forms, often in physical form. Access to new data also requires more effort because permits and licenses are required to legally access non-public data. Especially if there is sectoral ego between agencies as data owners. This is what service and information providers who implement Big Data analytics in Indonesia feel, that the data collection phase is the main challenge. In fact, in Indonesia, data for various types of needs is available and abundant, but the sources are scattered, so more effort is needed to obtain integrated data nationally.  Data Privacy On the one hand, data transparency is needed, but on the other hand, privacy is a sensitive issue and is often compromised through technological advances. Privacy relates to a person's personal data that must be protected. Much of the data used as Big Data, which is obtained directly from consumers, is personal data and is very vulnerable to misuse by other parties. When just one data requires guaranteed security, then when there is integration of data from several sources, the level of security must be further increased. Because the data stored is not small, but is related to many things.  Technology This is related to infrastructure and tools in Big Data operations, such as computing and analytical techniques, as well as storage media. It cannot be denied that when you want to utilize Big Data technology, you must also be ready with the technology, such as infrastructure and tools.  Human Resources In applying Big Data technology, human resources are needed with analytical skills and creativity, namely the ability to determine new methods that can be used to collect, interpret and analyze data, computer programming skills, and business skills, namely an understanding of business goals.

Therefore, it is difficult to obtain useful information in real time and determine which data should be stored, which should be discarded. The last challenge is data veracity. Much data changes all the time, so the veracity of the data becomes uncertain.

answer: First, as the name suggests, the size of big data is very large. Meanwhile, existing technology is not designed to process big data that has low locality or no locality, is dynamic, large in size, and cannot be loaded in memory. Therefore, in processing big data we have to return to statistical methods. Second, data has many variations and dimensions. In other words, data is diverse, heterogeneous, can be structured or unstructured. Then, speed is also a challenge. Data arrives continuously in the form of a data stream. Therefore, it is difficult to get useful information in real time and determine which data should be kept and which should be discarded. The final challenge is the correctness of the data. A lot of data changes all the time, so the truth of the data becomes uncertain.

question: What challenges exist when implementing Big Data?
ground_truth: When implementing Big Data, the following challenges exist: 1. Data Management and Storage 2. Data Processing and Analysis 3. Data Quality and Cleanliness 4. Data Security and Privacy 5. Data Integration 6. Skills Shortage 7. Infrastructure and Operational Costs 8. Scalability 9. Business Understanding 10. Regulations and Compliance
answer: 1. Data from various sources is stored on different platforms. A common big data management challenge in a company is the need to manage data from various sources, but the data received is stored on different platforms based on the type of data and the origin of the source. This gap will cause problems during the data collection and analysis process. 2. Classifying quality data. With so much data at their disposal, it will be difficult for employees to classify quality data. In the end, the analysis process does not focus on data that truly has value for the company's business progress. In addition, if employees have to classify quality data manually, then they will not get real-time data to find the latest trends. The inability to see data in real-time will have many significant negative impacts on the quality of decisions taken based on available data or what is usually called data-driven decisions. 3. Lack of employees who have the ability to analyze data. Even though times are increasingly advanced and modern, the reality is that many companies still do not have enough employees to analyze data properly. This problem occurs because the operation of the platform is complex, only certain employees can be relied on to analyze data. If the situation is like this, it will be difficult for companies to keep up with the pace of development of business competition, because the data analysis process takes a very long time. 4. Requires a lot of costs. The next big data management challenge is the large costs required to carry out an effective data analysis process. 5. Scalability problems As the company's business develops, the amount of data that will be produced will become increasingly uncontrollable. The increasing amount of data will create new problems in storing and managing data, because the process will become more complex. Many companies fail to manage their data effectively as their business grows. The big data analytics platform that has been used since the beginning does not have good enough capabilities to manage increasingly large amounts of data.

question: What challenges exist when implementing Big Data?
ground_truth: When implementing Big Data, the following challenges exist: 1. Data Management and Storage 2. Data Processing and Analysis 3. Data Quality and Cleanliness 4. Data Security and Privacy 5. Data Integration 6. Skills Shortage 7. Infrastructure and Operational Costs 8. Scalability 9. Business Understanding 10. Regulations and Compliance
answer: First, as the name suggests, the size of big data is very large. Meanwhile, existing technology is not designed to process big data that has low locality or no locality, is dynamic, large in size, and cannot be loaded in memory. Therefore, in processing big data we have to return to statistical methods. Second, data has many variations and dimensions. In other words, data is diverse, heterogeneous, can be structured or unstructured. Then, speed is also a challenge. Data arrives continuously in the form of a data stream. Therefore, it is difficult to get useful information in real time and determine which data should be kept and which should be discarded. The final challenge is the correctness of the data. A lot of data changes all the time, so the truth of the data becomes uncertain.

question: What challenges exist when implementing Big Data?
ground_truth: When implementing Big Data, the following challenges exist: 1. Data Management and Storage 2. Data Processing and Analysis 3. Data Quality and Cleanliness 4. Data Security and Privacy 5. Data Integration 6. Skills Shortage 7. Infrastructure and Operational Costs 8. Scalability 9. Business Understanding 10. Regulations and Compliance
answer: It is necessary to synchronize different data sources. As data sets become larger and more diverse, there is a big challenge to combine them into platforms. If this is ignored it will create gaps and lead to the wrong messages and insights.  Lack of professionals who understand Big Data analysis. With the exponential increase in data, the demand for Big Data scientists and analysts is growing. It is important for companies to hire a data scientist who has diverse skills because the work of a data scientist is multidisciplinary.  Get important insights through Big Data analysis. It is very important for companies that only relevant departments have access to this information. Real-time data can help researchers and companies provide the latest insights for decision making.  Getting volume data into a Big Data platform. Companies need to handle large amounts of data every day. The amount and variety of data available today can overwhelm data engineers and it is critical to make data accessibility easy and convenient for company owners and managers.  Uncertainty in the data management landscape. With the emergence of Big Data, new technologies and companies, the big challenge faced by companies in Big Data analysis is to know which technology is most suitable for them without any new problems and potential risks.  Data storage and quality. Popular data storage options such as data lakes warehouses are generally used to collect and store large amounts of unstructured and structured data in their native format. Missing data, inconsistent data, logic conflicts, and duplicate data all result in data quality challenges.  Data security and privacy. Big Data also involves potential risks regarding data privacy and security. Big Data tools are used for analysis and storage using different data sources. This ultimately leads to a high risk of data exposure and makes it vulnerable. Increasing amounts of data also raise privacy and security concerns.
